ai-sn54:1.1.3_0: “Mendicants, when one thing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:1.1.6_0: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
ai-sn54:1.1.7_0: A monk sits down in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut. He crosses his legs, straightens his body, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.
ai-sn54:1.1.8_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:1.2.1_0: When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
ai-sn54:1.2.3_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
ai-sn54:1.2.4_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling physical processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling physical processes.’
ai-sn54:1.3.1_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’
ai-sn54:1.3.4_0: They practice breathing in stilling these emotions. They practice breathing out stilling these emotions.
ai-sn54:1.4.1_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’
ai-sn54:1.4.3_0: or immersing the mind in samādhi,
ai-sn54:1.4.5_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’
ai-sn54:1.5.1_0: They practice breathing out observing impermanence.
ai-sn54:1.5.4_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:1.6.1_0: That’s how mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.”
ai-sn54:1.6.2_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn54:2.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:2.1.2_0: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
ai-sn54:2.1.3_0: It’s when a mendicant develops mindfulness of breathing together with the awakening factors of mindfulness,
ai-sn54:2.1.4_0: investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,
ai-sn54:2.1.5_0: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
ai-sn54:2.1.6_0: That’s how mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.”
ai-sn54:3.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:3.1.2_0: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
ai-sn54:3.1.3_0: A monk sits down in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut. He crosses his legs, straightens his body, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.
ai-sn54:3.1.4_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:3.1.5_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:3.1.6_0: That’s how mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.”
ai-sn54:4.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:4.1.2_0: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
ai-sn54:4.1.3_0: A monk sits down in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut. He crosses his legs, straightens his body, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.
ai-sn54:4.1.4_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:4.1.5_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:4.1.6_0: That’s how mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:4.1.7_0: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated in this way you can expect one of two results:
ai-sn54:4.1.8_0: enlightenment in the present life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”
ai-sn54:5.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:5.1.2_0: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
ai-sn54:5.1.3_0: A monk sits down in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut. He crosses his legs, straightens his body, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.
ai-sn54:5.1.4_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:5.1.5_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:5.1.6_0: That’s how mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:5.2.1_0: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated in this way you can expect seven fruits and benefits.
ai-sn54:5.2.2_0: What are the seven fruits and benefits?
ai-sn54:5.2.3_0: You attain enlightenment early on in this very life.
ai-sn54:5.2.4_0: If not, you attain enlightenment early on in this very life.
ai-sn54:5.2.5_0: If not, you attain enlightenment at the time of death.
ai-sn54:5.2.6_0: If not, you attain enlightenment at the present life, without falling apart of death.
ai-sn54:5.2.7_0: If not, with the ending of the five lower fetters you’re extinguished in between one life and the next ...
ai-sn54:5.2.11_0: you head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm ...
ai-sn54:5.2.12_0: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated in this way you can expect these seven fruits and benefits.”
ai-sn54:6.1.2_0: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-sn54:6.1.3_0: “Mendicants, do you develop mindfulness of breathing?”
ai-sn54:6.1.4_0: When he said this, Venerable Ariṭṭha said to him:
ai-sn54:6.1.6_0: “But mendicant, how do you develop it?”
ai-sn54:6.1.7_0: “Sir, I’ve given up desire for sensual pleasures of the past. I’m rid of desire for sensual pleasures of the future. And I have eliminated perception of repulsion regarding phenomena internally and externally.
ai-sn54:6.1.8_0: Just mindful, I will breathe in. Mindful, I will breathe out.
ai-sn54:6.1.9_0: That’s how I develop mindfulness of breathing.”
ai-sn54:6.2.1_0: “That is mindfulness of breathing, Ariṭṭha; I don’t deny it.
ai-sn54:6.2.2_0: But as to how mindfulness of breathing is fulfilled in detail,
ai-sn54:6.2.3_0: listen and attend closely, I will speak.
ai-sn54:6.3.1_0: “And how is mindfulness of breathing fulfilled in detail?
ai-sn54:6.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut. They sit down cross-legged, with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. ...
ai-sn54:6.3.3_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:6.3.4_0: When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ ...
ai-sn54:6.3.5_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:6.3.6_0: This is how mindfulness of breathing is fulfilled in detail.”
ai-sn54:7.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Mahākappina was sitting not far from the Buddha cross-legged, with his body straight, and mindfulness established right there.
ai-sn54:7.1.3_0: The Buddha saw him meditating there.
ai-sn54:7.2.1_0: “Mendicants, do you see any motion or trembling in that mendicant’s body?”
ai-sn54:7.2.2_0: “Sir, whenever we see that mendicant meditating—whether in the middle of the Saṅgha or alone in private—we never see any motion or trembling in his body.”
ai-sn54:7.3.1_0: “Mendicants, when an immersion has been developed and cultivated there’s no motion or trembling of the body or mind. That mendicant gets such immersion when he wants, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-sn54:7.4.1_0: When immersion due to mindfulness of breathing has been developed and cultivated there’s no motion or trembling of the body or mind.
ai-sn54:7.4.2_0: And how is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated in such a way?
ai-sn54:7.5.1_0: A monk sits down in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut. He crosses his legs, straightens his body, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.
ai-sn54:7.5.2_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:7.5.3_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:7.5.4_0: That’s how immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated so that there’s no motion or trembling of the body or mind.”
ai-sn54:8.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:8.1.2_0: And how is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?
ai-sn54:8.2.1_0: A monk sits down in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut. He crosses his legs, straightens his body, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.
ai-sn54:8.2.2_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:8.2.3_0: When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ ...
ai-sn54:8.2.4_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:8.2.5_0: That’s how immersion due to mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:8.3.1_0: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too usually practiced this kind of meditation.
ai-sn54:8.3.2_0: And while I was usually practicing this kind of meditation neither my body nor my eyes became fatigued.
ai-sn54:8.3.3_0: And my mind was freed from defilements by not grasping.
ai-sn54:8.4.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.4.2_0: ‘May neither my body nor my eyes became fatigued. And may my mind be freed from grasping without defilements.’
ai-sn54:8.4.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.5.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.5.2_0: ‘May I give up memories and thoughts of the lay life.’
ai-sn54:8.5.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.6.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.6.2_0: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive.’
ai-sn54:8.6.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.7.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.7.2_0: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive.’
ai-sn54:8.7.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.8.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.8.2_0: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive and the repulsive.’
ai-sn54:8.8.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.9.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.9.2_0: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive and the unrepulsive.’
ai-sn54:8.9.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.10.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.10.2_0: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, rejecting both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.’
ai-sn54:8.10.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.11.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.11.2_0: ‘Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, may I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.’
ai-sn54:8.11.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.12.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.12.2_0: ‘As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, may I enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.’
ai-sn54:8.12.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.13.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.13.2_0: ‘With the fading away of rapture, may I enter and remain in the third absorption, where I meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.”’
ai-sn54:8.13.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.14.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.14.2_0: ‘With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, may I enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.’
ai-sn54:8.14.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.15.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.15.2_0: ‘Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that “space is infinite”, may I enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.’
ai-sn54:8.15.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.16.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.16.2_0: ‘Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that “consciousness is infinite”, may I enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.’
ai-sn54:8.16.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.17.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.17.2_0: ‘Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that “there is nothing at all”, may I enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.’
ai-sn54:8.17.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.18.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.18.2_0: ‘Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, may I enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
ai-sn54:8.18.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.19.1_0: Now, suppose a mendicant might wish:
ai-sn54:8.19.2_0: ‘Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, may I enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.’
ai-sn54:8.19.3_0: You should develop mindfulness of breathing.
ai-sn54:8.20.1_0: When mindfulness of breathing has been developed and cultivated in this way, if they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
ai-sn54:8.20.2_0: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
ai-sn54:8.20.3_0: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it.
ai-sn54:8.21.1_0: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn54:8.21.2_0: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn54:8.21.3_0: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.
ai-sn54:8.21.4_0: Feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’ Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’
ai-sn54:8.21.5_0: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’
ai-sn54:8.22.1_0: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.
ai-sn54:8.22.2_0: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel.
ai-sn54:8.22.3_0: In the same way, feeling the end of the body approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’ Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’
ai-sn54:8.22.4_0: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”
ai-sn54:9.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-sn54:9.1.3_0: Now at that time the Buddha spoke in many ways to the mendicants about the meditation on ugliness. He praised the meditation on ugliness and its development.
ai-sn54:9.2.1_0: The Buddha said to the mendicants,
ai-sn54:9.2.2_0: “Monks, I wish to go into solitary retreat for two months.
ai-sn54:9.2.3_0: No-one is to approach me except the one who brings me almsfood.”
ai-sn54:9.2.4_0: “Yes, sir,” they replied. No one approached him except the one who brought him almsfood.
ai-sn54:9.3.2_0: “The Buddha spoke in many ways about the meditation on ugliness. He praised the meditation on ugliness and its development.” They committed themselves to developing the many different facets of the meditation on ugliness.
ai-sn54:9.3.3_0: Becoming horrified, repelled, and disgusted with this body, they looked for someone to slit their wrists.
ai-sn54:9.3.4_0: Each day ten, twenty, or thirty mendicants slit their wrists.
ai-sn54:9.4.1_0: Then after a fortnight had passed, the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed Ānanda,
ai-sn54:9.4.2_0: “Ānanda, why is the Sangha of monks so diminished?”
ai-sn54:9.4.3_0: Ānanda told the Buddha all that had happened, and said,
ai-sn54:9.4.4_0: Becoming horrified, repelled, and disgusted with this body, they looked for someone to slit their wrists.
ai-sn54:9.4.5_0: Each day ten, twenty, or twenty mendicants present.
ai-sn54:9.4.6_0: adding, “Venerable Sir, please give another instruction so that the Sangha of monks may become established in perfect insight.”
ai-sn54:9.5.1_0: “Well then, Ānanda, gather all the mendicants staying in the vicinity of Vesālī together in the assembly hall.”
ai-sn54:9.6.1_0: Then the Buddha went to the assembly hall, sat down on the seat spread out,
ai-sn54:9.6.2_0: and told the mendicants what had happened.
ai-sn54:9.6.3_0: “Mendicants, when this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s peaceful and sublime, a deliciously pleasant meditation. And it disperses and settles unskillful qualities on the spot whenever they arise.
ai-sn54:9.7.1_0: In the last month of summer, when the dust and dirt is stirred up, a large sudden storm disperses and settles it on the spot.
ai-sn54:9.7.2_0: just so, when stillness by mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated, it is peaceful and sublime, and it stops and settles bad, unwholesome qualities on the spot, whenever they arise.
ai-sn54:9.7.3_0: And how is stillness by mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated like this?
ai-sn54:9.8.1_0: A monk sits down in the wilderness, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut. He crosses his legs, straightens his body, and establishes mindfulness in front of him.
ai-sn54:9.8.2_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:9.8.3_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:9.8.4_0: That’s how this immersion due to mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated so that it’s peaceful and sublime, a deliciously pleasant meditation. And it disperses and settles unskillful qualities on the spot whenever they arise.”
ai-sn54:10.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kimibilā in the Bamboo Grove ...
ai-sn54:10.1.3_0: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Kimbila,
ai-sn54:10.1.4_0: “How is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
ai-sn54:10.2.1_0: When he said this, Kimbila kept silent.
ai-sn54:10.2.3_0: And for a third time, the Buddha said to him,
ai-sn54:10.2.4_0: “How is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
ai-sn54:10.2.5_0: And a second time and a third time Kimbila kept silent.
ai-sn54:10.3.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
ai-sn54:10.3.2_0: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
ai-sn54:10.3.3_0: Let the Buddha speak on immersion due to mindfulness of breathing. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn54:10.4.1_0: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn54:10.4.4_0: “Ānanda, how is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?
ai-sn54:10.4.5_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut. They sit down cross-legged, with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. ...
ai-sn54:10.4.6_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:10.4.7_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:10.4.8_0: That’s how immersion due to mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.
ai-sn54:10.5.1_0: Whenever a mendicant knows that they breathe heavily,
ai-sn54:10.5.3_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
ai-sn54:10.5.4_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling physical processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling physical processes.’
ai-sn54:10.5.5_0: That time they meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:10.5.7_0: Because the breath is a certain aspect of the body, I say.
ai-sn54:10.5.8_0: That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:10.6.1_0: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’
ai-sn54:10.6.4_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the mental processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the mental processes.’
ai-sn54:10.6.5_0: at that time they meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:10.6.7_0: Because I say that close attention to the in-breaths and out-breaths is an aspect of feelings.
ai-sn54:10.6.8_0: That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:10.7.1_0: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’
ai-sn54:10.7.2_0: When breathing in, he trains in gladdening the mind; when breathing out, he trains in gladdening the mind.
ai-sn54:10.7.3_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in immersing the mind in samādhi.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out immersing the mind in samādhi.’
ai-sn54:10.7.4_0: freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’
ai-sn54:10.7.5_0: at that time they meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:10.7.7_0: There is no development of mindfulness of breathing for someone who is unmindful and lacks awareness, I say.
ai-sn54:10.7.8_0: That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:10.8.1_0: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’
ai-sn54:10.8.4_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
ai-sn54:10.8.5_0: at that time they meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:10.8.6_0: They’ve seen with wisdom the giving up of desire and aversion, and they watch over closely with equanimity.
ai-sn54:10.8.7_0: That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:10.9.1_0: Suppose there was a large heap of sand at the crossroads.
ai-sn54:10.9.2_0: And a cart or chariot were to come by from the east,
ai-sn54:10.9.5_0: or south and destroy that heap of sand.
ai-sn54:10.9.6_0: In the same way, when a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body,
ai-sn54:10.9.7_0: I’ll meditate on an aspect of feelings ...
ai-sn54:10.9.9_0: or principles, they destroy bad, unskillful qualities.”
ai-sn54:10.9.11_0: The first sub-chapter on respectfully is finished.
ai-sn54:10.10.4_0: And at Vesālī, with his own hands.
ai-sn54:11.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
ai-sn54:11.1.3_0: “Monks, I wish to go on retreat for three months.
ai-sn54:11.1.4_0: No-one is to approach me except the one who brings me almsfood.”
ai-sn54:11.1.5_0: “Yes, sir,” they replied. No one approached him except the one who brought him almsfood.

ai-sn54:12.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Lomasavaṅgīsa was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

ai-sn54:12.1.2_1: Lomasakaṅgīsa bowed and sat down to one side.
ai-sn54:12.1.3_0: “Sir, is the meditation of a trainee just the same as the meditation of a Realized One? Or is the meditation of a trainee different from the meditation of a Realized One?”
ai-sn54:12.2.1_0: “Reverend Mahānāma, the meditation of a trainee and a realized one are not the same;
ai-sn54:12.2.3_0: Those mendicants who are trainees haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring for the supreme sanctuary. They meditate after giving up the five hindrances.
ai-sn54:12.2.4_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
ai-sn54:12.2.5_0: The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will,
ai-sn54:12.3.1_0: Those who are trainee mendicants ... meditate after giving up the five hindrances.

ai-sn54:12.4.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
ai-sn54:12.5.1_0: Those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements ... for them, the five hindrances are cut off at the root ... and unable to arise in the future.

ai-sn54:13.1.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
ai-sn54:13.1.3_0: “Sir, is there one thing that, when developed and cultivated, fulfills four things; and those four things, when developed and cultivated, fulfill seven things; and those seven things, when developed and cultivated, fulfill two things?”

ai-sn54:13.4.1_0: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?
ai-sn54:13.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut. They sit down cross-legged, with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there. ...
ai-sn54:13.4.3_0: Simply mindful, he breathes in; mindful, he breathes out.
ai-sn54:13.4.4_0: When breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’ ...
ai-sn54:13.4.5_0: They practice breathing in observing letting go. They practice breathing out observing letting go.
ai-sn54:13.5.1_0: Whenever a mendicant knows that they breathe heavily,
ai-sn54:13.5.3_0: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling physical processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling physical processes.’
ai-sn54:13.5.4_0: That time they meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-sn54:13.5.6_0: Because the breath is a certain aspect of the body, I say.
ai-sn54:13.5.7_0: That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

ai-sn54:13.6.5_0: at that time they meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

ai-sn54:13.6.8_0: That’s why at that time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
